H0.text: Hot spot is the landform least likely to be associated with tectonic plate movement that forms volcanoes when tectonic plates move, creating various landforms.

H1.text: Rift valley is the least likely landform associated with the tectonic plate movement that forms volcanoes.

H2.text: Subduction zone is the least likely landform associated with the tectonic plate movement that forms volcanoes when tectonic plates move and form different landforms.

H3.text: Transform boundary is the least likely landform associated with tectonic plate movements that form volcanoes.

A4.text: Arc volcanoes tend to produce dangerous eruptions because they are rich in water (from the slab and sediments) and tend to be extremely explosive. Krakatoa, Nevado del Ruiz, and Mount Vesuvius are all examples of arc volcanoes.

A5.text: Rift valleys are formed as a result of the pulling apart of the lithosphere due to extensional tectonics.

A6.text: The Dead Sea lies in a rift which results from a leftward discontinuity in the left lateral-moving Dead Sea Transform fault.

A7.text: Hotspot volcanoes are formed as tectonic plates move over stationary mantle plumes, creating volcanic chains like the Hawaiian-Emperor seamount chain.

A8.text: Subduction zones are directly linked to volcanic activity due to the melting of the subducting slab and the formation of arc volcanoes.

A9.text: Transform boundaries typically do not produce volcanoes because they involve lateral movement rather than the convergence or divergence of plates.

A10.text: Rift valleys are formed by extensional tectonics and can host volcanic activity, as seen in the East African Rift.
